thread.title: Warren Buffett cashes in some of his reinsurance bet with Munich Re stake sale
thread.title_full: Warren Buffett cashes in some of his reinsurance bet with Munich Re stake sale

title: Warren Buffett cashes in some of his reinsurance bet with Munich Re stake sale
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Sep 29, 2015, 17:46 BST - UK Markets closed Warren Buffett cashes in some of his reinsurance bet with Munich Re stake sale By Marion Dakers | Telegraph – 53 minutes ago 0.00 
US billionaire has reduced his stake in the German firm from 12pc to less than 10pc 
The investment billionaire Warren Buffett has cashed in some of his bet on the world of reinsurance, reducing his stake in Munich Re after five years as the German group’s biggest shareholder. 
The Sage of Omaha has cut his holding from 12pc to 9.7pc of the company, which, based on Munich Re’s market value of €27.6bn, would have produced a windfall of €635m. 
Mr Buffett and his Berkshire Hathaway (Sao Paolo: BERK34F.SA - news ) investment business built up a stake in Munich Re in 2010, building on his position in US reinsurance. 
“We are pleased that Warren Buffett has been a significant shareholder for many years,” said Joerg Schneider, chief financial officer of Munich Re. 
"In the 135-year history of our business, we have often seen changes to our shareholder structure. Most of our shareholders now come from countries other than Germany, and the percentage of private investors has increased strongly.” 
Munich Re said it had paid out dividends of more then €6bn since 2010, when Mr Buffett built up his investment. Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) in the firm fell less than 1pc to €166 after the announcement, compared to €109 when Berkshire first revealed it was acquiring a stake 
The shares have also been supported by an ongoing buyback, which in March saw the firm promise to take €1bn-worth of shares off the market. 
Berkshire Hathaway is a long-standing supporter of the reinsurance business, which sells protection to traditional insurance firms to spread the risk of large claims, such as hurricane damage or aviation disasters. 
The industry has attracted large amounts of capital from institutional investors hoping to generate better returns through reinsurance premiums than the meagre yield on bonds in recent years. 
However, this influx of capital has put pressure on prices, which are already low thanks to a relatively quiet few years for natural disasters. 
After the annual reinsurance conference in Monte Carlo earlier this month, Fitch Ratings said prices looked set to fall further as "fierce supply-side competition persist[s]". However, Munich Re said it saw signs of the pressure easing. 
Mr Buffett told shareholders at a meeting in May that "it’s a business whose prospects have turned for the worse and there’s not much we can do about it". 
Berkshire also owns General Re, one of the world’s biggest reinsurers, and sells its own reinsurance contracts, although executives have said the business has been more picky about the reinsurance contracts it pursued in recent months. 
Berkshire Hathaway also sold down its 3.1pc stake in rival reinsurer Swiss Re (LSE: 0QL6.L - news ) over the summer, concluding a relationship during which Mr Buffett helped to rescue the company shortly after the financial crisis (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
